questions.text: Atavism is resemblance of features to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Grandfather Atavism refers to the reappearance of ancestral traits in an individual that were absent in recent generations but present in distant ancestors. As atavism involves traits inherited from distant ancestors, such as a grandparent or even further back in the lineage. These traits could include physical characteristics, genetic features, or behavioral patterns that seem to "skip" generations. For instance, a person might exhibit features like a recessive genetic trait, a physical anomaly, or a behavioral pattern that was present in an ancestor but not in the immediate parents. A. Mother This option is incorrect because the term "atavism" does not refer to traits inherited directly from a parent, such as the mother. Traits inherited from the mother are considered a part of normal genetic inheritance and do not qualify as atavistic features. B. Father This option is also incorrect because, like the mother, traits inherited directly from the father are not considered atavistic. Such traits are part of standard Mendelian inheritance and do not involve the reappearance of ancestral features. C. Neighbour This option is incorrect and irrelevant because genetic inheritance cannot occur from a neighbor. Atavism strictly pertains to ancestral traits within one's genetic lineage and not external influences or unrelated individuals.

choices.text: Toddler with bruise and laceration on forehead, plus older bruise over shin, mother says he ran into a chair
3 month old infant with bruise on right forearm and left buttock; parent states infant rolled off changing table
Mild scald burn with splash marks on trunk of 6 month infant; parent states she accidently spilled coffee
Bite mark in shoulder of 9 months with distance between canines about 2cm; father believes 2 year old brother has bitten recently.

questions.text: Which presentation is most indicative of possible child abuse?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 3 month old infant with bruise on right forearm and left buttock; parent states infant rolled off changing table • Baby may be able to kick himself over, from his tummy to his back, as early as age 4 months. It may take him until he's about 5 or 6 months to flip from back to front, though, because he needs stronger neck and arm muscles for that manoeuvre. • The injuries mentioned under options A, B and C is accordance with the history given. Two years old child will have 1x4=4 canines Baby may be able to kick himself over, from his tummy to his back, as early as age 4 months (Explanation). In option B – the baby is 3 months

choices.text: Minimum imprisonment for forced male homosexual sodomy is 7 years
Minimum imprisonment for forced Homosexual sodomy is 10 years
Minimum imprisonment for bestiality is 7 years

questions.text: True statement is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation: • Sec.377 IPC. Unnatural offences.—Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished with 1[imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. • As per recent amendment in rape law, minimum imprisonment for rape is 10 years and forced anal intercourse (forced means without consent) amounts to rape.

questions.text: In maceration which of the following statement is not true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Greenish discoloration • Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis. • The changes of maceration were well studied and classified by Langley. • Amniotic membrane should be intact (exclusion of air) with abundant liquor amnii. • The earliest sign is skin slippage which is seen in 12 hours after death of the fetus. • The typical features are seen in 3-4 days. • The skin is coppery brown in colour and has a sweetish disagreeable odour. • Large blebs appear at 24 hours. • The body is soft, flaccid and flattens out when placed on a level surface. • There will be hypermobility of the joints. • The skull bones are separated with collapsed vertebral column.

questions.text: Sexual intercourse by a husband with his wife during separation without wife’s consent is punishable under Section
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 376B of IPC • 376A IPC - Punishment for causing death or resulting in persistent vegetative state of victim. • 376B IPC - Whoever has sexual intercourse with his own wife, who is living separately, whether under a decree of separation or otherwise, without her consent, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine. Bailable and Cognizable (on complaint of victim). • 376C IPC - Sexual intercourse by person in authority. • 376D IPC – Gang rape

choices.text: Vaginal swab need not be taken
The fetus can be aborted after her consent
Examination can be done by a female doctor with a female attendant
Urine pregnancy test is not necessary

questions.text: A 14-years-old rape victim was brought to the hospital with 22 weeks of pregnancy. All of the following are correct statements regarding the case, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation: • Vaginal swab is not needed because the rape incidence is not recent. • Urine pregnancy test is not necessary. • Foetus cannot be terminated, because the victim is minor so she cannot give consent. • A woman can give consent for termination of pregnancy only after 18 years of age, if termination is indicated.

questions.text: Sexual arousal from enemas is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sexual arousal from enemas is known as Klismaphilia Klismaphilia is a specific paraphilia where individuals derive sexual pleasure or excitement from the administration of enemas. This may be due to the physical sensations involved, psychological associations, or a combination of both. The condition is often categorized under paraphilic interests and can range in intensity among individuals. It is distinct in its focus on the use of enemas, making this the correct answer. A. Agalmatophilia This option is incorrect because Agalmatophilia refers to sexual arousal from statues, dolls, or mannequins. It is unrelated to the use of enemas or any activity involving them. B. Coprolagnia This option is incorrect as Coprolagnia is the sexual arousal derived from feces or defecation. While enemas involve the rectum, Coprolagnia is centered on feces itself, making this unrelated to Klismaphilia. C. Mysophilia This option is incorrect because Mysophilia involves sexual arousal from filth, dirt, or uncleanliness. Although enemas are associated with cleaning the body, Mysophilia pertains to a fascination with unclean conditions, which is the opposite of what an enema typically achieves.

questions.text: In a fetus nails reach the tip of the fingers at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 8th month Age related changes in fetus: • 4th month : Sex is recognized, lanugo is visible • 5th month : Vernix caseosa appears on the body • 6th month : Hair appears on the head • 7th month : Pupillary membrane disappears • 8th month : Nails reach the tip of the fingers. Testicles: • 6th month : Lies close to kidneys (on psoas) • 7th month : Left near the external inguinal ring, Right near the internal inguinal ring. • 8th month : Left in the scrotum, Right near the external inguinal ring. • 9th month: Both in the scrotum.

choices.text: Males who are impotent to a particular woman
Unmarried woman in whom contraceptives has failed
Young married woman with illicit sexual relation with a colleague

questions.text: Pseudocyesis is usually observed in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Childless wife nearing menopause • Pseudocyesis is also known as False or Spurious or Phantom or Hysterical or Imaginary pregnancy. • In this condition, the woman believes or imagines that she is pregnant when she is not pregnant. • It is purely psychological. • It is generally believed that false pregnancy is caused by changes in the endocrine system of the body, leading to the secretion of hormones that cause physical changes similar to those during pregnancy. • It may be seen in a childless married lady nearing menopause. • The woman has subjective symptoms of pregnancy in form of enlarged abdomen, breast changes with amenorrhea. • The woman have imaginary thoughts that fetus is growing inside her womb. • X-ray or sonography can confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Age of the fetus of weight 1000g, foot length 8cm, thick nails, opened eyelids, pupillary membrane disappeared, testis in external inguinal ring, crown rump length is 23cm is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 7 months • At 7th month of intra uterine life of fetus: • Crown-heel length: 35 cm, Crown –rump length : 23 cm, Foot length : 8 cm, Weight: 900-1200 gram. • Skin is dusky red, thick and fibrous and covered with vernix. • The eyelids are separated. • Pupillary membrane disappeared. • Scalp hairs are about 1 cm long. • Nails thick and up to fingertip. • Meconium in descending colon. • Left testes near the external inguinal ring and right near the internal inguinal ring.

questions.text: ‘Lochia’ is the discharge seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) After delivery • LOCHIA: It is a vaginal discharge seen after delivery, which is as a result of healing process of placental site. o Lochia Rubra: First 4-5 days, bright red in colour. o Lochia Serosa: Next 4 days, serous and paler in colour. o Lochia Alba: After 9-10 days, thicker, scantier and white or yellowish white. • It disappears in 2-3 weeks.

questions.text: The fertilisation of two ova released at two different menstrual cycles refers to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Superfoetation • SUPERFECUNDATION: Superfecundation is the fertilization of two or more ova from the same cycle by sperm from separate acts of sexual intercourse. Heteropaternal superfecundation occurs when two different males father fraternal twins. In common usage, the term superfecundation is often used instead of heteropaternal superfecundation. • SUPERFOETATION: Superfetation means the fertilization of an ovum from a subsequent ovulation in a woman who is already pregnant. Two fetuses are born either at the same time showing different stages of development, or two fully developed fetuses are born varying from 1-3 months. • FETUS PAPYRASEOUS (Fetus compressus): In twin pregnancy, one fetus may grow and develop more than other fetus. The second under-developed fetus may get compressed and flattened. Such fetus is termed as fetus papyraseous • FECUNDATION AB EXTRA: Fertilisation of ova by the semen deposited on vulva or inner aspect of the thigh.

questions.text: Motile spermatozoa found on a wet mount of vaginal secretions are indicative of intercourse within the past
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 12 hours The presence of motile spermatozoa in a wet mount of vaginal secretions is indicative of intercourse within the past 12 hours. Sperm motility is a sign of viability and activity, which is influenced by factors like temperature, pH, and the environment of the vaginal canal. After ejaculation, motile spermatozoa remain active for a limited time, usually up to 12 hours, in the vaginal secretions before they lose motility due to the body's natural processes. Detecting motile spermatozoa on a wet mount is a useful indicator for estimating the time frame of recent intercourse. A. 6 hours This option is incorrect because motile spermatozoa can remain active for up to 12 hours in the vaginal environment. While they can certainly be observed within 6 hours, this timeframe does not encompass the full duration of their motility, making this option too restrictive. C. 24 hours This option is incorrect because motile spermatozoa typically lose their movement within 12 hours due to the vaginal environment's conditions, such as changes in pH and temperature. While sperm may still be present in a non-motile state after 12 hours, they are no longer motile at 24 hours. D. 48 hours This option is incorrect as motile spermatozoa are unlikely to survive and remain active for 48 hours in vaginal secretions. While non-motile sperm may persist for a longer duration (up to 72 hours or more), motility is usually lost within 12 hours, making this time frame too long to be accurate for motile sperm.

questions.text: After birth the umbilical cord falls in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 5-6 days Changes in Umbilical cord: • 2 hours- Blood clots in cut end. • 24 hours- Vessel begins to close. • 12-24 hours-Cord attached to child shrinks and dries. • 36-48 hours-Inflammatory ring at the base. • 2-3 days-Mummifies. • 5-6 days-Falls off and leaves an ulcer. • 10-12 days-Cicatrizes

questions.text: The test to know the presence of air in the stomach and intestine in autopsy on new born is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Breslau’s second life test • Hydrostatic test/Breslau’s first life test/Raygat’s test: This test is conducted to know whether the child has breathed or not. • First, the ligature is tied on the bronchi and lungs are separated. • Each lung is individually placed in water, then is cut into 12-20 pieces and placed in water to see whether they float or sink. • A small piece of liver may serve as control. • If they float, they are each squeezed between thumb and index finger to remove the tidal air. • If all the pieces float, it indicates that the respiration has taken place. • If all the pieces sink, it means the child has not breathed. • If some pieces sink and some pieces float, it indicates partial or feeble respiration. Stomach-bowel test (Breslau’s second life test): • This is a good corroborative test. • It is based on the principle that when respiration is established, there is a probability that air is swallowed and may pass into the stomach and small intestine. • It is performed by placing double ligatures at each end of the stomach and at different parts of the small intestine. • The various parts are tested for floatation, and if positive results are shown, they are punctured under water, then the contained may be seen to escape to the surface. • If no escape, the test is negative.

questions.text: The test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ploucquet's Test The test in which the weight of the lungs is compared with the body weight is known as Ploucquet's Test. It is a post-mortem examination method used to determine whether a newborn had taken a breath of air (indicating live birth). This test is based on the principle that the lungs of a live-born infant will weigh more relative to the body weight due to the aeration of the lungs. In contrast, the lungs of a stillborn infant remain denser and heavier due to the absence of aeration. Incorrect Options: B. Fodere's Test This option is incorrect because Fodere's Test involves examining whether the lungs float in water to determine if a newborn has breathed air. It does not compare the weight of the lungs to body weight, making it unrelated to Ploucquet's Test. C. Wredin’s Test This option is incorrect as Wredin's Test refers to the comparison of the ratio of the lungs' weight to the thymus weight in neonates. It is a separate method used in forensic investigations but does not involve comparing lung weight to body weight, which is the focus of Ploucquet's Test. D. Static Test This option is incorrect because the Static Test involves evaluating the physical state of the lungs, such as whether they float or sink in water, to determine aeration. It does not involve weight comparisons with the body and is different in purpose and methodology from Ploucquet's Test.

questions.text: Karyotyping of foetus may be done from all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Monocyte • Karyotyping is the process of pairing and ordering all the chromosomes of an organism, thus providing a genome-wide snapshot of an individual's chromosomes. • Karyotypes are prepared using standardized staining procedures that reveal characteristic structural features for each chromosome. Clinical cytogeneticists analyze human karyotypes to detect gross genetic changes—anomalies involving several megabases or more of DNA. • Karyotypes can reveal changes in chromosome number associated with aneuploid conditions, such as trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). • Careful analysis of karyotypes can also reveal more subtle structural changes, such as chromosomal deletions, duplications, translocations, or inversions. In fact, as medical genetics becomes increasingly integrated with clinical medicine, karyotypes are becoming a source of diagnostic information for specific birth defects, genetic disorders, and even cancers. For karyotyping, the cells need to be arrested in the metaphase stage for separating the chromosomes. As the monocytes do not divide, they cannot be used for karyotyping.

questions.text: False Negative Hydrostatic test in a live born foetus may be seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Atelectasis The hydrostatic test, also known as the lung floatation test, is a forensic procedure used to determine whether a newborn has taken a breath. In this test, the lungs are placed in water; if they float, it suggests the presence of air, indicating respiration. Conversely, if the lungs sink, it implies the absence of respiration. However, certain conditions can lead to false-negative results, where the test indicates no respiration despite the infant having breathed. Atelectasis refers to the incomplete expansion or collapse of the lungs. In newborns, this condition can occur due to various factors, such as prematurity or respiratory distress, leading to insufficient aeration of the lung tissues. As a result, even if the infant has taken breaths, the lungs may not retain enough air to float during the hydrostatic test, causing a false-negative outcome. Incorrect Responses: A. Emphysema: Emphysema is a chronic lung condition characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls, leading to enlarged air spaces. This condition is typically associated with adults and is not relevant to newborns. Therefore, it does not affect the hydrostatic test results in infants. B. Putrefaction: Putrefaction refers to the decomposition of body tissues after death, leading to gas formation. These gases can cause the lungs to float during the hydrostatic test, potentially resulting in a false-positive result, not a false-negative. D. Artificial Respiration: Artificial respiration involves manually providing breaths to an infant. This process can introduce air into the lungs, causing them to float during the hydrostatic test. However, this would lead to a false-positive result rather than a false-negative.

choices.text: Child fictitiously claimed by a woman
Child is born after artificial insemination homologous
Second born of a twin pregnancy

questions.text: What is meant by 'SUPPOSITIOUS child'?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Child fictitiously claimed by a woman A supposititious child refers to an infant fraudulently presented as the biological offspring of someone, typically to claim inheritance or social status. Historically, this practice involved procuring a baby and passing them off as one's own, especially when an heir was needed. This option accurately defines a supposititious child. In historical contexts, such as Ancient Rome, there were instances where individuals would introduce a non-biological child into their family to secure an heir or claim certain privileges. To prevent such fraudulent claims, laws were enacted, and measures like employing multiple midwives during childbirth were taken to ensure the legitimacy of the offspring. Incorrect Responses: B. Child born out of wedlock: A child born out of wedlock is termed an illegitimate child, not a supposititious child. Illegitimacy pertains to the circumstances of the child's birth rather than any fraudulent claim about their parentage. C. Child born after artificial insemination homologous: Artificial insemination homologous involves using the husband's or male partner's sperm to achieve pregnancy. The resulting child is biologically related to the parents and does not involve any fraudulent claims, thus not fitting the definition of a supposititious child. D. Second born of a twin pregnancy: In a twin pregnancy, the second-born child is simply the younger twin. There is no implication of fraudulent parentage, so this option is unrelated to the concept of a supposititious child.

questions.text: The definite signs of pregnancy include all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Positive HCG test • Positive HCG test is only probable sign of pregnancy because this test can be positive even in cases of diseases like chorionic carcinoma & hydatidiform mole and up to two weeks after pregnancy. • The definite/positive signs of pregnancy are 1. Foetal parts and movements: Active foetal movements are felt by placing the hands on the abdomen from 16-18 weeks and may be seen by 5th month. Foetal parts such as head and limbs can be distinctly felt after 24 weeks of gestation. 2. Fetal heart sounds: FHS are heard between 18 and 20 weeks by stethoscope/foetoscope. The fetal heart rate is 160/minute at 5th month and 120/minute at 9th month. Fetal heart sounds are not felt: • When the fetus is dead • When there is excessive quantity of liquor amnii • When abdominal wall is very fat • When examination is made before 18 weeks of pregnancy 3. X-Ray: At 15-16 weeks, fetal parts can be detected with certainty, but occasionally parts are detected as early as 10 weeks. The shadows on X-ray are: • Crescentic or annular shadow of the skull • Beaded appearance of vertebrae • Step ladder pattern of ribs and • Irregular linear shadows of limbs 4. Ultrasonography: Gestational sac is seen as white ring by 6th week. Distinct echos from the embryo within the gestational ring by 7th week. Foetal heart beat can be made out by 10th week.

questions.text: The term ‘Affiliation cases’ refer to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Suits for adoption Legitimacy: • The fact that any person was born during the continuance of a valid marriage between his mother and any man, or within 280 days after its dissolution, the mother remaining unmarried, shall be conclusive proof that he is the legitimate son of that man, unless it can be shown that the parties to the marriage had no access to each other at any time when he could have been begotten. Posthumous child: • Child born after death of a father in a legally married couple. Orphan child: • It is a child whose parents are dead. Affiliation cases (Suits for adoption): • A woman may allege a particular man to be the father of her illegitimate child and file a case in the court for fixing the paternity. • As per Sec 125 Cr.P.C., a first class Magistrate can sanction a monthly allowance of any sum depending upon the circumstances of the case for the maintenance of such child.

questions.text: False accusation by adopted children of being mistreated by their adoptive mothers is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cinderella syndrome • Battered baby syndrome is also known as: - Caffey’s syndrome - Non accidental injuries of childhood (NAI) - Inflicted Traumatic Brain Injury (ITBI) - Inflicted Childhood Neurotrauma (ICN) • A battered child is a child who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. • In addition, there may be deprivation of love, care, affection and nutrition. • Usually seen in a child less than 3 years, but may be seen up to 5 years of age. • Incidence is slightly more in males. • Unwanted child. • Young parents (20-30years) with low socio-economic status. • Inconsistent history and findings of physical examination (Mismatch). • Multiple bruises of different colors in same individual (Different age). • Shaken Baby Syndrome (Infantile Whiplash Syndrome) is a form of child abuse. Usually occur in children <2 years, but may be seen up to the age of 5 years. • Cinderella Syndrome: False accusation by adopted children of being mistreated or neglected by their adoptive mothers is known as Cinderella syndrome.

questions.text: Emmenagogues are the drugs which
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increase menstrual blood flow • Ecbolics are the drugs which increase the uterine contractions. - Ergot is the most commonly used ecbolic. - Others include Pituitary extract, Quinine, Cotton root bark, Diachylon (lead oleate), Gossypium etc. • Emmenagogues act by increasing the menstrual blood, flow and causing expulsion. - Sanguinarin, estrogens, senecio, Oil of savin, Borax, Apiol, are chief emmenagogues. • Diaphoretics increase sweating. - The excessive sweating can be produced by application of heat (e.g.: Blankets, Hot water bottles and administration of hot beverages will cause increased perspiration). - The best diaphoretic is Pilocarpine Nitrate, 5 mg subcutaneously. The other diaphoretics are alcohols, salicylates and Antipyretics • Emetics are the drugs which induce vomiting.

questions.text: Which is NOT a feature seen on the baby born of precipitate labour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prominent caput succedaneum • In Precipitate Labour, all 3 stages of labour are merged together and the mother may deliver the baby without her knowledge suddenly. • The baby may fall into the lavatory pan and die of drowning or suffocation or it may fall on the ground and may die of head injury. • In case of skull fracture usually it is fissured and limited to parietal bones or may be pond fracture. • If occurs it is usually seen in multiparae with roomy pelvis and small foetus. • Caput succedaneum and cephalohematoma are not seen. • The umbilical cord if torn is torn near the fetal end.

questions.text: The percentage of fetal haemoglobin at birth is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 80% Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is the primary form of hemoglobin present during fetal development, facilitating efficient oxygen transport in the womb. At birth, the percentage of HbF in a newborn's blood typically ranges from 50% to 95%, with an average around 80%. This high concentration of HbF is essential for meeting the oxygen demands of the developing fetus. Option B accurately reflects the average percentage of fetal hemoglobin present at birth. This value is consistent with observed physiological data, where HbF levels are high immediately after birth and gradually decrease over the first few months of life as adult hemoglobin (HbA) production increases. Incorrect Responses: A. 94%: While 94% is within the possible range of HbF percentages at birth, it represents the higher end of the spectrum. Since 80% is a more commonly observed average value, option A is less accurate compared to option B. C. 7-8%: This percentage is significantly lower than the typical HbF levels observed at birth. Such low levels are more characteristic of infants several months after birth, as HbF gradually decreases and is replaced by adult hemoglobin (HbA). D. 0%: At birth, it is highly unlikely for a newborn to have 0% HbF, as HbF is the primary hemoglobin during fetal development and persists in significant amounts immediately after birth.

questions.text: Killing of a child by its own parents is called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Filicide The term filicide refers to the act of a parent killing their own child. This encompasses both mothers and fathers who commit such acts, regardless of the child's age. Filicide is a tragic and complex phenomenon influenced by various psychological, social, and economic factors. Option C accurately defines the act of a parent killing their own child, encompassing both mothers and fathers. This term is used in legal and psychological contexts to describe such tragic events. Incorrect Responses: A. Feticide: Feticide refers to the intentional killing of a fetus, typically before birth. It does not involve the death of a child after birth and is not committed by parents in the same context as filicide. B. Neonaticide: Neonaticide is the act of killing a newborn within the first 24 hours of life. While it is a form of filicide, it specifically pertains to the immediate post-birth period. Therefore, it is a subset of filicide, not a separate term for the general act. D. Infanticide: Infanticide refers to the killing of an infant, typically defined as a child under one year of age. While it is a form of filicide, it is more specific in terms of the child's age. Therefore, it is a subset of filicide, not a separate term for the general act.

questions.text: Excessive sexual interest in females is termed as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nymphomania • Satyriasis: Uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire in a man. • Nymphomania: Excessive sexual desire and drive in females. • Hybristophilia: Sexual arousal is obtained by being with a partner known to have committed an outrage, cheating, lying, known infidelities or crime, such as rape, murder, or armed robbery. • Coprolalia: Sexual excitement is obtained by using obscene language.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done as per MTP Act, maximum up to a gestational age of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 24 weeks As per the MTP Amendment Act, 2021, the gestational limit for medical termination of pregnancy has been extended to 24 weeks for certain categories of women, including survivors of rape and incest, minors, and women with physical disabilities. This extension aims to provide these women with greater access to safe abortion services. Incorrect Responses: A. 12 weeks: Under the MTP Act, a pregnancy can be terminated up to 12 weeks with the opinion of one registered medical practitioner. This limit applies to general cases without specific circumstances. B. 16 weeks: The MTP Act does not permit termination of pregnancy up to 16 weeks. The permissible gestational age is up to 12 weeks with one medical opinion and up to 20 weeks with two medical opinions. C. 20 weeks: The MTP Act allows for termination up to 20 weeks with the opinions of two registered medical practitioners. This limit applies to general cases without specific circumstances.

choices.text: Any part of living child comes out
Child is completely out of mothers private parts
Child is completely born and cries
Child is completely born and shows signs of respiration

questions.text: Live birth according to Indian law is when:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Any part of living child comes out • A child is live born according to English law when, after complete extrusion from the mother, irrespective of the attachment or severance of the cord, it exhibits some signs of life like crying, movements of limbs, twitching of eye lids, respirations and pulsation. • In India, if any part of a living child had been brought forth, though the child may not have breathed or been completely born =, it constitutes live birth. The evidences in respect of live-birth or circumstantial and from post mortem examination.

choices.text: Age of accused is less than 7 years

questions.text: Best defense for Rape is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Age of accused is less than 7 years In Indian law, the best defense against a charge of rape is that the accused is under seven years of age. According to Section 82 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), a child under seven years old is considered incapable of committing an offense. This provision reflects the principle that children below this age lack the mental capacity to understand the nature of their actions and, therefore, cannot be held criminally responsible. Option D is correct because Section 82 of the IPC explicitly states that nothing is an offense if done by a child under seven years of age. This legal provision provides a complete defense against criminal liability for individuals in this age group. Incorrect Responses: A. Accused is intoxicated: Voluntary intoxication is not a defense under Indian law. The law holds individuals accountable for their actions, even if they were intoxicated at the time of committing the offense. B. Accused is impotent: Impotence is not a recognized defense against a charge of rape. The offense of rape is defined by the act of non-consensual penetration, and impotence does not negate the occurrence of this act. C. Accused is in lucid interval: A person in a lucid interval, meaning a temporary period of sanity, is still held responsible for their actions during that time. The defense of insanity requires that the individual was incapable of understanding the nature of their act due to unsoundness of mind at the time the offense was committed.

questions.text: After birth, the ductus venous closes by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4 days The ductus venosus is a vital fetal blood vessel that allows oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava, facilitating efficient circulation during fetal development. After birth, as the newborn's liver becomes functional and the placenta is no longer in use, the ductus venosus undergoes closure. This closure is typically completed within 3 to 7 days post-birth, with structural closure usually occurring within the first week. Incorrect Responses: A. 2 days: While functional closure of the ductus venosus occurs shortly after birth, structural closure typically takes longer, usually within the first week. Therefore, 2 days is too early for complete closure. B. 3 days: Although the ductus venosus begins to close functionally shortly after birth, structural closure usually occurs within the first week. Therefore, 3 days is too early for complete closure. D. 10 days: By 10 days post-birth, the ductus venosus should have closed structurally. Therefore, 10 days is too late for closure.
